metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of hydrometeorological observation network (an observation system of meteorological elements gradient of Sidaoqiao superstation, 2013)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Hydrometeorological observation network obtained from an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Sidaoqiao Superstation between 11 July, 2013, and 31 December, 2013. The site (101.137° E, 42.001° N) was located on a tamarix (Tamarix chinensis Lour.) surface in the Sidaoqiao, Dalaihubu Town, Ejin Banner, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 873 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (HC2S3; 5, 7, 10, 15, 20 and 28 m, towards north), wind speed profile (010C; 5, 7, 10, 15, 20 and 28 m, towards north), wind direction profile (020C; 15 m, towards north), air pressure (CS100; in waterproof box), rain gauge (TE525M; 28 m, towards south), four-component radiometer (CNR4; 10 m, towards south), two infrared temperature sensors (SI-111; 10 m, towards south, vertically downward), two photosynthetically active radiation (PQS-1; 10 m, towards south, one vertically upward and one vertically downward), soil heat flux (HFP01SC; 3 duplicates with G1 below the tamarix; G2 and G3 between plants, -0.06 m), a TCAV averaging soil thermocouple probe (installed on 17 July, 2013, TCAV; -0.02, -0.04 m), soil temperature profile (109ss-L; 0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2 and -1.6 m), and soil moisture profile (install on 7 December, 2013, ML2X; -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2 and -1.6 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_5 m, Ta_7 m, Ta_10 m, Ta_15 m, Ta_20 m and Ta_28 m; RH_5 m, RH_7 m, RH_10 m, RH_15 m, RH_20 m and RH_28 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_5 m, Ws_7 m, Ws_10 m, Ws_15 m, Ws_20 m and Ws_28 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_15 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_up and PAR_down) (μmol/ (s m^-2)), average soil temperature (TCAV, ℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2 and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_80 cm, Ts_120 cm and Ts_160 cm) (℃), and soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_80 cm, Ms_120 cm and Ms_160 cm) (%, volumetric water content).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The wind speed (10 m height) data were missing before 12 November, 2013 because of the sensor problem. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2013-9-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Li et al. (2013) (for hydrometeorological observation network or sites information), Liu et al. (2011) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Verification.Question: Can data collection methods from eddy covariance systems effectively measure latent heat flux in arid agricultural areas?
Is it challenging to accurately estimate component temperatures using composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions?

Disjunctive.Question: What is the primary data collection technique for measuring soil and canopy temperatures in oasis-desert ecosystems: thermal infrared cameras, eddy covariance systems, or satellite-based observations?

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection methods are used in observing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems?
Concept Completion.Answer: eddy covariance system, scintillometer, automatic weather stations

Concept Completion.Question: Where are the observation sites for the hydrometeorological data collection located in the context of the Heihe River Basin?
Concept Completion.Answer: middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin

Concept Completion.Question: When were the soil water content sensors installed in the SIDAOQIAO superstation observation setup?

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: One challenge is the degradation of ecological environments in arid regions, such as the drying up of rivers, degradation of vegetation, and increased land desertification, especially in inland river basins like the Tarim River basin and Lake Urmia basin.

Example.Question: Please provide an example of a dataset used to study hydrometeorological conditions in a desert ecosystem.
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset includes long-term energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, as well as auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters collected from automatic weather stations in the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin.

Feature Specification.Question: What features of meteorological parameters are crucial for observing energy and water vapor exchanges in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Feature Specification.Answer: air temperature, wind speed, humidity, four-component radiations, turbulent fluxes

Feature Specification.Question: What are the distinguishing characteristics of soil and canopy component temperature measurements used in evapotranspiration models?
Feature Specification.Answer: thermal infrared cameras, soil and canopy pixels, sensible and latent heat fluxes, radiometric temperatures

Quantification.Question: How many layers are used for measuring air temperature and wind speed in a meteorological observation system within this domain?

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods used in the 黑河生态水文遥感试验 compare to the methods applied in the oasis–desert systems for capturing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange?
Comparison.Answer: The 黑河生态水文遥感试验 involves a detailed meteorological observation network with multiple layers of sensors measuring variables like wind speed, air temperature, and soil moisture at different heights and depths, ensuring comprehensive meteorological data capture. In contrast, the data collection in oasis–desert systems uses eddy covariance and scintillometers for capturing turbulent fluxes and employs automatic weather stations to gather comprehensive hydrometeorological data, along with vegetation and soil parameters. Both approaches emphasize capturing detailed meteorological and environmental data, yet they utilize different instruments and setups tailored to their respective research focus.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in the challenges faced during data collection in the 黑河生态水文遥感试验 and the oasis–desert ecosystem studies?
Comparison.Answer: Both the 黑河生态水文遥感试验 and oasis–desert ecosystem studies face challenges related to ensuring accurate and complete data collection under varying environmental conditions. In the 黑河生态水文遥感试验, challenges include ensuring data completeness and handling missing or erroneous data, which is marked with specific indicators. Meanwhile, oasis–desert ecosystem studies must address environmental degradation issues, such as land desertification and ecological imbalances, while also managing data quality from long-term observations. Despite these differences, both emphasize robust data processing and quality control procedures.

Interpretation.Question: How do the observed patterns in soil temperature and moisture data inform the understanding of energy exchange processes in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The observed patterns in soil temperature and moisture data, collected at various depths, provide critical insights into the energy exchange processes between the soil and atmosphere in oasis–desert ecosystems. These measurements help infer how soil heat flux and moisture variations contribute to surface energy balance and the regulation of the local microclimate.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the effectiveness of using thermal infrared cameras and the eddy covariance system in measuring evapotranspiration in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of thermal infrared cameras and the eddy covariance system in measuring evapotranspiration in arid regions can reveal the complexities of accurately estimating surface fluxes. These instruments help separate soil and canopy component temperatures, enabling better validation of evaporation and transpiration estimates, even in environments with strong advection and heterogeneous land cover.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of measuring evaporation and transpiration in arid oasis-desert systems using ground-based methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Evaporation and transpiration are difficult to measure on the ground in arid regions due to the limitations in current composite temperature separation approaches and errors caused by image classification, especially with varying vegetation abundance. The uncertainties in atmospheric upwelling radiation, transmittance, and component temperature estimation further complicate accurate measurement.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are long-term observations crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observations are crucial because they provide a quantitative understanding of the interactions between oasis and desert systems, which are essential for maintaining ecological stability and supporting sustainable development. These observations help in recognizing the balance necessary for sustaining the oasis environment amidst the challenges posed by climate change and human activities.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes uncertainties in estimating soil and canopy component temperatures in strongly advective environments?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Uncertainties arise from errors in determining surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from composite radiometric temperatures. This is exacerbated by classification errors in image pixels, which misidentify soil pixels as vegetation, leading to overestimation of canopy temperature. Additionally, ignoring factors like atmospheric radiation and transmittance can further contribute to these uncertainties.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects of using a multi-layered meteorological observation system on the quality and reliability of climate data collected in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a multi-layered meteorological observation system, such as the one described with sensors at different heights, can enhance the quality and reliability of climate data by providing detailed vertical profiles of meteorological variables like wind speed and temperature. This setup helps capture microclimatic variations and can lead to more accurate modeling of surface-atmosphere interactions. However, challenges such as sensor maintenance and data consistency across layers need to be addressed to ensure data reliability.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of incorporating isotopic techniques in validating evapotranspiration measurements in oasis-desert systems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating isotopic techniques, such as stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, in validating evapotranspiration measurements can provide precise partitioning of evaporation and transpiration components, leading to more accurate estimations of water fluxes in oasis-desert systems. This approach enhances the understanding of water cycle dynamics and supports water resource management in arid regions. Yet, it also requires careful calibration and interpretation of isotope data, which can be complex and resource-intensive.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of using the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model in the context of evapotranspiration estimation for vegetated landscapes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives of using the TSEB model in the context of evapotranspiration estimation for vegetated landscapes include accurately estimating evaporation, transpiration, and total evapotranspiration by considering the heterogeneous nature of the landscape. The model aims to improve the understanding and management of the terrestrial water cycle and water resources by providing reliable estimates through the separation of soil and canopy component temperatures, which are validated using field observations and isotopic techniques.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to have long-term observational datasets for understanding energy and water vapor exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Long-term observational datasets are necessary for understanding energy and water vapor exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems because they provide critical insights into the interactions between oases and deserts, which are vital for ecological security and sustainable development. These datasets help in recognizing the basic characteristics and dynamics of these exchanges over time, contributing to the protection of ecological stability and supporting socioeconomic development in arid and semi-arid regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What processes are involved in ensuring the quality and integrity of meteorological and hydrological data collected from remote sensing networks in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The processes involved in ensuring the quality and integrity of meteorological and hydrological data include daily data checks to ensure completeness (ensuring 144 data points per day), marking missing data with a specific placeholder (-6999), removing duplicate records, deleting data outside the physical or instrumental range, and highlighting questionable data with red markings. The date and time are standardized into a single column, and the data is named according to a specific rule (AWS+Station Name).

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are advanced remote sensing instruments utilized to measure soil and vegetation temperatures for evapotranspiration estimation in heterogeneous landscapes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Advanced remote sensing instruments, such as a high-resolution thermal infrared camera, are used to measure soil and canopy component temperatures. These temperatures are then used as inputs for the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model. The thermal camera captures thermal images from which soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures are extracted. These temperatures are converted to radiation temperatures using incoming long-wave radiation and emissivity values. The process involves classifying thermal images into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to collect and process long-term data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Long-term data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems are collected using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer for turbulent flux data, along with automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data. These observations include radiation, soil heat flux, temperature and humidity profiles, wind speed and direction, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. Data processing involves collecting, processing, and archiving data while maintaining quality control. The processed data includes supplementary vegetation and soil parameters and is shared through data centers.

Enablement.Question: What specific data processing and quality control procedures enable the accuracy and reliability of datasets in hydrometeorological studies?
Enablement.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. These steps ensure the accuracy and reliability of datasets in hydrometeorological studies.

Enablement.Question: How do observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems enable a better understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange dynamics?
Enablement.Answer: Observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems, which include long-term measurements of energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, as well as auxiliary hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters, enable a comprehensive understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange dynamics.

Enablement.Question: What technologies or methods enable the measurement of turbulent flux data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The measurement of turbulent flux data in oasis–desert ecosystems is enabled by the use of an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, which provide half-hourly data.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise in ensuring accurate and comprehensive data collection in oasis–desert ecosystems, and what methods can be employed to address these challenges?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face ecological challenges such as drying up of rivers, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. Ensuring accurate data collection might involve long-term observations and the use of automatic weather stations, eddy covariance systems, and scintillometers to obtain comprehensive energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data.

Expectation.Question: Why might existing data collection methods for estimating evapotranspiration in heterogeneous land surfaces be insufficient, and what improvements could be made?
Expectation.Answer: One-source models may not accurately estimate surface evapotranspiration due to the heterogeneous nature of landscapes. The TSEB model improves this by using soil and canopy component temperatures to better estimate E, T, and ET. Improvements could involve using high-resolution thermal cameras and refining the separation of soil and canopy temperatures.

Expectation.Question: What are the expectations regarding the collection and quality control of hydrometeorological data in arid regions, and what techniques can enhance these processes?
Expectation.Answer: The expectation is to collect comprehensive hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, and moisture profiles. Techniques to enhance these processes include using automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period and implementing thorough data processing and quality control procedures.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the challenges faced in the accurate measurement of energy balance components in heterogeneous land surfaces?
Judgmental.Answer: Accurately measuring energy balance components in heterogeneous land surfaces like those covered by mixed soil and vegetation is indeed challenging. The complexity arises from factors such as varying resistances to energy exchange and the difficulty of distinguishing between soil and vegetation contributions using composite temperature approaches. These challenges are compounded by environmental conditions like strong advection, making precise measurements difficult.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the potential for expanding the existing datasets to include more comprehensive vegetation and soil parameters?
Judgmental.Answer: Expanding existing datasets to include more comprehensive vegetation and soil parameters could significantly enhance the understanding of oasis-desert ecosystems. These parameters are crucial for detailed analysis of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. Incorporating additional data on vegetation types, soil composition, and moisture levels would provide a more holistic view and possibly improve model validation and accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I don’t quite understand how data quality control is ensured when collecting meteorological and soil data in arid regions.
Assertion.Answer: The data collection process involves ensuring 144 data entries daily, with missing data marked by -6999, removing duplicate records, and deleting data that exceeds physical or instrument limits. Additionally, data with uncertainties are marked in red, and consistent formatting for date and time is maintained.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about how the variation in soil and canopy component temperatures is accurately measured and accounted for in such complex environments.
Assertion.Answer: In the research, soil and canopy component temperatures were measured using a high-resolution thermal camera. These temperatures were then calculated by classifying visible and NIR images into soil and canopy pixels. The radiation temperatures were derived from thermal infrared temperatures, considering incoming long-wave radiation and emissivities.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore different data collection methods for observing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems and discuss their potential challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: In the field of oasis–desert ecosystems, data collection methods include the use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for turbulent flux measurements, as well as automatic weather stations for gathering hydrometeorological data such as soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, and gradients of air temperature and humidity. Challenges include maintaining long-term datasets, ensuring data quality control, and addressing environmental degradation issues such as land desertification and drying up of water bodies in arid regions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and describe potential datasets that could be integrated with existing hydrometeorological observations to enhance the understanding of oasis–desert interactions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets that could be integrated with existing hydrometeorological observations include datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems, containing long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes. Additional auxiliary data involving vegetation and soil parameters, as well as groundwater table data, could further enhance understanding. These datasets are crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and supporting sustainable development goals.
